snippet.title: Stockland focuses on inclusivity | Photos
snippet.content:
New facilities: An artist's impression of the five star parents' room that will soon open at the revamped Stockland Green Hills.
A quite room for children with sensory disorders or intellectual disabilities is among the new facilities to be unveiled at Stockland Green Hills in the coming months. A new five star parents' room - where children can be changed, fed or given some time out from the hustle and bustle of the shopping centre - is also part of the $412 million revamp of retail precinct in Maitland's east. The quiet room was designed as a calm, safe space in a low sensory environment for parents and children. It's expected to open in November. "We believe it is important to remove the barriers experienced by the four million Australians with a disability, so they can have the same access and opportunities that we do," Stockland development manager Daniel Brabant said.

exit "We are proud to be delivering the quiet room facility as part of the Stockland Green Hills redevelopment, allowing people with sensory disorders a safe place while shopping - making it a much less stressful experience." Quiet rooms and retreats featured prominently in research Stockland conducted in 2015 to find out what sort of facilities customers wanted. A spokesperson for the organisation said Stockland opened two quiet rooms at its Shellharbour shopping centre last year, which "have proved very successful". "Children with sensory and intellectual disabilities often find shopping centres very challenging with common issues surrounding anxiety, crowds and sensory overload," the spokesperson said. Next month, a new state-of-the-art parents' room will open at Green Hills, including change tables, private feeding rooms, a microwave to warm bottles and a children's play area. New disability amenities, including an adult change room, a changing table and assistance lifter will also open. "We are proud to not only deliver first class retail, but also first class amenities for the people of Maitland," Mr Brabant said. The major shopping centre upgrades are expected to be complete in mid 2018.
